sentences: Ole Børud (born December 6, 1976) is a Norwegian singer, songwriter, instrumentalist, producer, and engineer known both for his solo recordings and as a member of the groups Arnold B. Family, Schaliach, Extol, and Fleshkiller.
section: N/A

sentences: Børud, son of Norwegian gospel singer Arnold Børud, began performing music at age five as part of Arnold B. Family, a group which would compete in the Melodi Grand Prix three times.
section: N/A

sentences: At age twelve, he released a Christian children's music album.
section: N/A

sentences: He later ventured into hard rock and heavy metal bands, first in the two-man project Schaliach and then in Extol and, briefly, the hardcore punk band Selfmindead.
section: N/A

sentences: Since the early 2000s, he has also recorded several solo albums in West Coast, pop, funk, and jazz styles: Chi-Rho (2002), Shakin' the Ground (2008), Keep Movin (2011), Someday at Christmas (2012, in collaboration with Samuel Ljungblahd), Stepping Up (2014), and Outside the Limit (2019).
section: N/A

sentences: He re-joined Extol in 2012, and in 2016 he co-founded a heavy metal side-project, Fleshkiller.
section: N/A

sentences: Børud has also performed for Torun Eriksen and Sofian and collaborated with Larvik Stroband and the Oslo Gospel Choir, and has contributed to two hymn compilations, Takk, gode Gud, for alle ting: 20 sanger fra Barnesalmeboka and Søndagsskolen Synger (both in 2008).
section: N/A

sentences: He has regularly appeared on various Norwegian television shows, including Det store korslaget and Stjernekamp, and in 2017 provided backing choral vocals in Jowst's performance of "Grab the Moment" in the 2017 Eurovision contest.
section: N/A
== Musical career ==

sentences: Musical career ==
section: == Musical career ==
== Musical career == | === Arnold B. Family ===

sentences: Arnold B. Family ===
section: == Musical career == | === Arnold B. Family ===

sentences: Born in Hamar, Norway, Børud started his musical career at the age of five years as a singer in his family's Christian pop group Børud-gjengen, later renamed Arnold B. Family.
section: == Musical career == | === Arnold B. Family ===

sentences: Highly popular within Norway, Arnold B. Family participated three times in the national finals for the Eurovision Song Contest, landing in the top ten all three times.
section: == Musical career == | === Arnold B. Family ===

sentences: The group took second place in 1995 for its song "La oss feire livet" ("Let Us Celebrate Life").
section: == Musical career == | === Arnold B. Family ===

sentences: In 1988, at age twelve, he made a solo debut with the Christian children's album Alle Skal Få Vite Det!.
section: == Musical career == | === Arnold B. Family ===

sentences: Børud has said that he no longer remembers much about the recording sessions.
section: == Musical career == | === Arnold B. Family ===

sentences: Almost thirty years later, in 2017, his niece Lisa Børud sang the song "Kjærligheten seirer" ("Love Wins") from the album when she competed in the talent show Stjernekamp.
section: == Musical career == | === Arnold B. Family ===
== Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===

sentences: Heavy metal and hard rock =
section: == Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===
== Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===

sentences: In the 1990s, Børud ventured into heavy metal, teaming up in 1995 with Peter Dalbakk to form a short-lived doom metal project called Schaliach, for which he played guitar, bass and drums.
section: == Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===

sentences: The group released one album, Sonrise, in 1996, and was noted for its "huge" sound, Metallica-influenced guitar style, and strong classical influences, which were likened to a "metal symphony".
section: == Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===

sentences: He joined Extol in 1996, where he played guitar and bass and provided background singing.
section: == Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===

sentences: Extol performed a highly technical mixture of death metal and progressive metal, incorporating other extreme metal styles as well as hardcore punk, orchestral music, jazz, and folk music.
section: == Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===

sentences: After recording two albums with the group, Burial and Undeceived, he left to further pursue his solo career in 2001, but briefly rejoined the group to record its third album, Synergy.
section: == Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===

sentences: In 2012, he rejoined the group, which reformed as a trio, and helped record its fifth, self-titled release.
section: == Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===

sentences: In the early 2000s, he also served for a brief period as a guitarist for the hardcore punk band Selfmindead.
section: == Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===

sentences: On February 12, 2016, Peter Espevoll of Extol announced that Børud had formed a new side-project, Fleshkiller, with his former Schaliach bandmate Dalbakk.
section: == Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===

sentences: Børud himself later announced that drummer Andreas Skorpe Sjøen also joined the band.
section: == Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===

sentences: In January 2017, it was announced that Dalbakk left the band and was replaced by Elisha Mullins.
section: == Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===

sentences: The first studio album, Awaken, debuted September 15, 2017.
section: == Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===

sentences: Børud also was featured as a vocalist and guitarist on the progressive death metal band Cognizance's single "Malignant Domain", released August 22, 2019.
section: == Musical career == | === Heavy metal and hard rock ===
== Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: As a solo artist ===
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: Børud's first solo release as an adult, Chi-Rho (2002), featured a pop rock sound and consisted of covers of various Christian music performers such as Whiteheart, Dogs of Peace, and Rebecca St. James.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: However, Børud considers his subsequent release, Shakin' the Ground, his true solo debut, as it was the first featuring original music.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: In 2009, he was featured along with Samuel Ljungblahd and Miriam Gardner on the Joakim Arenius and Praise Unit three-track single "The Mission Field", from the album of the same name.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: In 2011, he released Keep Movin, which peaked at no. 27 on the Norwegian charts and no. 15 on the Swedish charts.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: A single was released for that album in 2011 as well, "She's Like No Other".
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: That same year, he performed live with Santa Fe and the Fat City Horns, a concert which was later released on DVD in 2013.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: In 2012, Børud was featured on the song "Get Ready" by INC the Choir on the album Higher.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: He also appeared in 2013 on the Lars-Erik Dahle album Step into the Water for the song "Barrytown", and with his father, Arnold, on the Rune Larson song "All Shook Up" from the album Tidens Gate.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: Later that year collaborated with Samuel Ljungblahd for a stand-alone Christmas single, "Mary's Boy Child", released on November 8, and on December 23 the pair released a full Christmas album, Someday At Christmas.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: The album charted at no. 39 in Norway and no. 13 in Sweden.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: That year Børud also released a best-of compilation, The Best.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: His next studio release was Stepping Up, released on November 24, 2014, which was accompanied by the single "Maybe".
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: On March 8, 2017, Lars-Erik Dahle, featuring Børud, released a remixed version of "Barrytown" — "Barrytown [Waveform Five Mix]" — as a single.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: Also that year, Ljungblahd and Børud collaborated once again for the Christmas single "O Holy Night", released on November 10.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: On January 18, 2019, Trine Rein featured Børud on her single "Where Do We Go".
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: His latest studio album, Outside the Limit, was released on September 20, 2019.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: Three singles have been released for Outside the Limit: "Good Time", released on November 16, 2018, "Fast Enough", released on February 1, 2019, and "Outside the Limit", released August 28, 2019.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: From Shakin' the Ground onward, Børud adopted a Westcoast style that mixes together funk, r&b, and soul, and Stepping Up is described as jazz pop in the vein of Steely Dan and Stevie Wonder.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: Outside the Limit was thought to hearken back to the 1970s and was compared to Chicago, Donald Fagen, Nikki Corvette, Al Jarreau, Phil Collins, Bruno Mars, Toto, and even Daft Punk.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: Other noted influences include Quincy Jones, George Duke, Earth, Wind and Fire, and Prince.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: Børud himself stated in one interview that his influences "could be a lot.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: Anything from Death to Yes to Steely Dan to Jason Falkner and so forth."
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: Per Albrigtsen of Østlands-Posten called Børud one of the foremost artists in the funk and soul genres.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: Børud has also performed for Torun Eriksen and Sofian, and collaborated with Larvik Stroband and the Oslo Gospel Choir.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: Also, in 2008, he collaborated with Kåre Conradi and Ingelin Reigstad Norheim along with girls from the Jeløy Church's Children's and Youth Choirs to release Takk, gode Gud, for alle ting: 20 sanger fra Barnesalmeboka, a compilation album of 20 hymns.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: The same year, he collaborated on another hymn compilation, Søndagsskolen Synger, with Ann Kristin Wenneberg, Marianne Bondevik, Hans Esben Gihle, and Voxkids.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: He appeared on the show Det store korslaget on Norway's TV 2 in 2010, and in the Eurovision Song Contest 2017, Børud sang in the backing chorus for Jowst's song "Grab the Moment".
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: In 2018, he competed in Stjernekamp, during which he performed a duet with Lisa Børud.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: He was eliminated in the show's semi-finals.
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: On April 13, 2020, Børud was featured along with Kine L. Fossheim on the single and music video "Together We Stand".
section: == Musical career == | === As a solo artist ===

sentences: The song was released by Gospel Explosion, a choral project led by Leif Ingvald Skaug.

sentences: As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, Skaug began holding online choir rehearsals, in which individuals from 70 different countries participated.
